abstracts.cdata!:
The Fiscal Consolidation Credit Project
            for Djibouti had a satisfactory outcome with likely
            sustainability, moderate institutional development and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the Borrower.
            Technical difficulties, not anticipated during the
            preparation, and associated with the implementation of the
            pension reform and reconciliation of human resources
            database required two extensions in the project closing
            date.  Lessons were learned in the areas of choice of
            instrument; project preparation; and project supervision.
            Lessons included the following: A strong link exists between
            the use of technical knowledge and expertise in the
            preparation and program success. There are environments in
            which our traditional lending instruments are inadequate.
            Evaluating the internal institutional context and the
            internal decision-making process is necessary to mitigate
            the likelihood of failure.  Adjustment credits in
            capacity-poor environments demand monitoring and evaluation
            mechanisms even more thorough than those of traditional
            adjustment operations. There is a clear correlation between
            the capacity on the ground and the closeness of supervision
            to be provided.

display_title.display_title:
Djibouti - Fiscal Consolidation
            Credit Project  : Djibouti - Fiscal Consolidation Credit Project

5085366.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fiscal Consolidation Credit Project
            will support fiscal sustainability through structural, and
            institutional reforms, to positively impact public finances.
            Consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy, and
            conditional on its successful implementation, the project
            will lay the foundation for future support to the
            country's economic growth, and reform agenda. Project
            actions will improve budgetary management, particularly in
            clearing domestic payment arrears, will contain the public
            sector wage bill, implement a parametric reform to improve
            the viability of the existing pay-as-you-go pension system,
            and, strengthen the financial management of key public
            enterprises that provide infrastructure services, thus
            initiating a process of sector liberalization, and
            privatization. Although risks include weak institutional
            capacity, resistance by interest groups, and slippages in
            the macroeconomic program, these will be mitigated by
            focusing on few key reforms through the provision of
            technical assistance, and, by implementing reforms in
            collaboration with interested parties, including workers and
            employers. As per the potential downturn in macroeconomic
            stabilization, the project will complement the policy
            actions supported by the International Monetary Fund, by
            helping the authorities meet such targets.
